_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Ampersand Chowchilla Biomass LLC is located approximately 2.5 miles south west of CA-99, and 2 miles north of CA-152.

The facility has developed a Risk Management Program to address California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program requirements (California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Sections 2735-2785).  The facility is extremely diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. The facility staff is highly trained and utilizes log sheets and employee rounds to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using ammonia for NOx emission control. The facility has a qualified Anhydrous Ammonia Contractor to assist with their maintenance. 

 

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

The facility has a commitment to its workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Ammonia NOx Reduction system. The facilitys policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Ammonia NOx Reduction system is used to maintain the concentration of NOx in the exhaust from a Biomass burner arrangement at acceptable levels.  No chemical reactions occur during the storage of an Ammonia NOx Reduction system; ammonia injection into exhaust stack is outside the scope of the regulation and therefore is not included.  The operation of an Ammonia NOx Reduction system requires controlling the ammonia (NH3) pressure for proper injection into the system.  The Ammonia is stored in a vessel and kept at required pressure through the use of a vaporizer that withdraws liquid ammonia from the bottom of the tank, vaporizes the liquid and returns the vapor into the storage tank.  The tank has

welded pipe that leaves the top, which allows vapor flow through a pressure regulator valve that is connected directly to the biomass fuel combustor.  The injection point is the boundary of the system that is regulated by CalARP.

 

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario 

Per the CalARP Regulations one worst case analysis has been defined.  RMP*Comp was used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook.  This worst case release scenario is highly unlikely to occur because of active mitigation measures that can be taken and weather conditions that are unlikely as well.

Alternative Release Scenario

The meteorological conditions specified by regulation for alternative release scenarios were used.  RMP*Comp was used to determine the maximum downwind endpoint distance.  The downwind distance for this alternative release scenario is significantly less than that for the worst-case scenario.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook. 

Risk Considerations

Although the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst-case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety systems to make the worst case type of event not credible.  In addition to the safety practices and personnel of the facility, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event (e.g., In the event of a release, sudden rupture and flashing of ammonia would be highly turbulent.  Turbulence causes entrainment of air and the released vapor dilutes much more quickly than is s

hown in the model).

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with an ammonia release:

- There are process valves to permit isolation of any leaks in place without exposing anyone to the anhydrous ammonia.

- Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) is used by plant personnel, as necessary.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this CalARP Program, key prevention program elements were implemented by the facility to manage process safety issues associated with the use of ammonia for NOx Reduction.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  As ammonia is "self alarming" due to its pungent odor, even minor releases are readily noticeable.  The Prevention Program 3 elements include:

- Process Safety Information

- Process Hazard Analysis

- Operating Procedures

- Training

- Mechanical Integrity

- Management of Change

- Pre-startup Safety Review

- Compliance Audits

- Incident Investigation

- Employee Participation

- Hot Work Permit

- Contractors

- Emergency Response Plan



In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Business Emergency Plan (BEP).  The entire prevention program elements are kept in the CalARP/EPA/RMP Compliance Workbook located onsite.  The prevention program elements satisfy the requirements of CalARP, EPA RMP, and OSHA PSM.



 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no CalARP applicable releases of ammonia at the Ampersand Chowchilla Biomass LLC in at least the past five years.  The facility was in service more than five years before the date of submission, was taken out of commission and commissioned by Ampersand Chowchilla Biomass LLC during 2007.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The fa

cility has filed a Chemical Inventory Business Emergency Plan with Madera County and this plan includes:

- Emergency Alarm Procedures

- Evacuation Procedures

- Safety and Health Considerations

- Notification Procedures

 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Several studies have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  These studies include the following: Process Hazard Analysis, Seismic Assessment and Hazard Assessment.  All recommendations are tracked to completion.
